definition: A programming language used to create interactive effects within web browsers.
A function that retains access to its lexical scope even when executed outside that scope.
The standard language for creating web pages and web applications.
A language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML.
A lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write, and easy for machines to parse and generate.
A set of rules and protocols for building and interacting with software applications.
A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine, allowing server-side scripting.
A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, particularly single-page applications.
A technique for creating asynchronous web applications, allowing web pages to update without reloading.
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
A standard language for managing and manipulating databases.
An architectural style for designing networked applications, using HTTP requests to access and use data.
A query language for APIs that allows clients to request only the data they need.
A binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine, enabling high-performance applications on the web.
A superset of JavaScript that adds static types, enabling better tooling and error checking.
A type of application software delivered through the web, built using common web technologies, and intended to work on any platform that uses a standards-compliant browser.
A platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers, allowing for consistent environments across development and production.
An open-source system for automating the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.
An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services, which implement business capabilities.
A development practice where developers integrate code into a shared repository frequently, with automated builds and tests.
A software release process that automatically deploys every change that passes automated tests to production.
A project management and software development approach that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and customer feedback.
An agile framework for managing complex projects, focusing on iterative progress through sprints.
A visual workflow management method that helps teams visualize their work, limit work in progress, and maximize efficiency.
A set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops), aiming to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality.
A subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn from data, identify patterns, and make decisions with minimal human intervention.
A decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across many computers in such a way that the registered transactions cannot be altered retroactively.
The delivery of computing services over the internet, allowing for flexible resources, faster innovation, and economies of scale.
The network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies to connect and exchange data with other devices and systems over the internet.
The practice of protecting systems, networks, and programs from digital attacks, theft, and damage.
Extremely large data sets that may be analyzed computationally to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behavior and interactions.
A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world, often using headsets and motion tracking.
An interactive experience where real-world environments are enhanced with computer-generated perceptual information.
An area of computing focused on developing computers that use quantum bits (qubits) to perform calculations at speeds unattainable by classical computers.
A field of artificial intelligence that focuses on the interaction between computers and humans through natural language.
A distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the location where it is needed, improving response times and saving bandwidth.
The fifth generation of mobile network technology, offering faster speeds, lower latency, and greater connectivity for devices.
A cloud computing execution model where the cloud provider dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources, allowing developers to focus on writing code without managing servers.
An interdisciplinary field that uses scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to extract knowledge and insights from structured and unstructured data.
The graphical representation of information and data, using visual elements like charts, graphs, and maps to make complex data more accessible and understandable.
The overall experience a user has when interacting with a product or service, focusing on usability, accessibility, and pleasure provided in the interaction.
The means by which a user interacts with a computer, software, or application, including the layout of elements on the screen.
An approach to web design that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes, ensuring a good user experience.
The practice of developing software applications that can run on multiple operating systems or platforms without requiring significant changes.
A web application that interacts with the user by dynamically rewriting the current page, rather than loading entire new pages from the server.
A web development strategy that emphasizes core webpage content first, then enhances the experience for users with more advanced browsers or devices.
A software application that enables users to create, manage, and modify content on a website without needing specialized technical knowledge.
The practice of optimizing web pages to rank higher in search engine results, increasing the visibility of a website.
The practice of making websites usable for people with disabilities, ensuring that all users can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact with the web.
A system of distributed servers that deliver web content to users based on their geographic location, improving load times and availability.
A protocol providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection, enabling real-time data transfer between client and server.
A type of application software delivered through the web, built using common web technologies, and intended to work on any platform that uses a standards-compliant browser.
A binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine, enabling high-performance applications on the web.
A security feature that helps prevent a variety of attacks, including cross-site scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks, by specifying which dynamic resources are allowed to load.
A security feature implemented in web browsers that allows or restricts web pages from making requests to a domain different from the one that served the web page.
A free, open-source project that provides web browsers and mobile applications with real-time communication via simple application programming interfaces (APIs).
A script that the browser runs in the background, separate from a web page, enabling features that don't need a web page or user interaction, such as push notifications and background sync.
A query language for APIs that allows clients to request only the data they need, making it more efficient than traditional REST APIs.
A suite of different technologies allowing you to create reusable custom elements with their functionality encapsulated away from the rest of your code.
A programming concept where a virtual representation of the UI is kept in memory and synced with the real DOM, improving performance and user experience.
The management of the state of an application, often using libraries or frameworks to handle data flow and state changes efficiently.
A design pattern in which an object receives other objects that it depends on, promoting loose coupling and easier testing.
A programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program, allowing for asynchronous programming in environments like JavaScript.
A programming paradigm that allows for non-blocking operations, enabling the execution of code while waiting for other operations to complete.
An object representing the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value.
A syntactic feature in JavaScript that allows for writing asynchronous code in a more synchronous style, making it easier to read and maintain.
A programming paradigm that treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions and avoids changing state and mutable data.
A programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code: data in the form of fields, and code in the form of procedures.
General reusable solutions to common problems in software design, providing templates for how to solve issues in a consistent way.
The process of restructuring existing computer code without changing its external behavior, improving its readability and maintainability.
The systematic examination of computer source code intended to find bugs, improve code quality, and ensure adherence to coding standards.
A system that records changes to a file or set of files over time so that you can recall specific versions later, often using tools like Git.
A development practice where developers integrate code into a shared repository frequently, with automated builds and tests to detect issues early.
A software release process that automatically deploys every change that passes automated tests to production, ensuring rapid delivery of new features.
An iterative approach to software development that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and customer feedback throughout the development process.
An agile framework for managing complex projects, focusing on iterative progress through sprints and regular team meetings.
A visual workflow management method that helps teams visualize their work, limit work in progress, and maximize efficiency.
A set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops), aiming to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality.
An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services, which implement business capabilities independently.
An approach to building and running applications that fully exploit the advantages of cloud computing, including scalability, flexibility, and resilience.
